posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
We have a project we‚Äôre working on where we want to run two robots with similar subsystems (different constants) off of one codebase. We want to switch the constants based on which roborio we are running on (based on serial number), but we also want the deployment of the code to halt if the serial number that the code is deploying to doesn‚Äôt match the one we specify in code. This could happen if we have to swap a rio for some reason. Is it possible to check the roborio serial number at compile time?

Thanks!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
the compile step isn‚Äôt aware of any roboRIO connection at all, so there‚Äôs no way to do exactly what you‚Äôre imagining, but you can make the robot behavior depend on the roboRIO serial number.

we use a single code base for all of our robots, and use the serial number of the RoboRIO to select mechanism implementations, or, as you suggest, specific constants.  for example, we have a gyro interface and a few implementations, and we select which implementation to choose using a ‚Äúswitch‚Äù statement in a factory.  it‚Äôs not a compile-time thing, it‚Äôs a run-time thing.  there‚Äôs only one set of code to deploy, it just does something different based on the serial number it‚Äôs running on.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked: Yeah, there are a couple of thread on CD talking about runtime checks in the Rio serial number. We aren‚Äôt so sure because of the edge case where you have to replace your Rio and end up deploying the wrong code or getting a runtime error.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
we have a class called ‚ÄúIdentity‚Äù that maps the serial number to an enum that the code actually uses, so if you have to replace the rio, it‚Äôs a one-line change to adjust the code to behave the same way with the new serial number.

IMHO it‚Äôs way better to just have one code base, so that the phrase ‚Äúdeploy the wrong code‚Äù no longer ever happens.  we don‚Äôt even use branches.  there is ONE code base.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôd recommend that you have one codebase and switch the constants based on a file you create on the roboRIO.

VH-109 Radio Hazard Electrical

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: i‚Äôve seen this pattern too, and i‚Äôm puzzled by it, it seems like having two places to look is worse than one.  what‚Äôs the argument for it?

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked: I‚Äôm not sure what you mean by having two places to look.  The file simply identifies the robot, and then the codebase has different constants for each robot.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: oh, you mean the file just has a key in it, i see.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
Just to insert some context here: Our team is running a V1/V2 strategy this year, meaning that for early week events, we bring our V1 robot, and for later events we bring our (hopefully) better V2 robot. We are worried that at events, we will end up in a situation where we have to swap a rio for one reason or another, which results in a runtime error or constants and such being instantiated incorrectly to the other robot.

truher:

we have a class called ‚ÄúIdentity‚Äù that maps the serial number to an enum that the code actually uses, so if you have to replace the rio, it‚Äôs a one-line change to adjust the code to behave the same way with the new serial number.

IMHO it‚Äôs way better to just have one code base, so that the phrase ‚Äúdeploy the wrong code‚Äù no longer ever happens. we don‚Äôt even use branches. there is ONE code base.

Yeah, we agree that one codebase is the way to go, but we have some reservations about deployment to the wrong robot when roborios get replaced. We may not have time to implement that one line adjustment before we have to be out on the field.

bovlb:

I‚Äôd recommend that you have one codebase and switch the constants based on a file you create on the roboRIO.

We had considered this too, but have the same reasons to doubt its robustness. If we have to swap a rio, the file needs to be added back to the new rio, which may be forgotten in the hustle and bustle of a busy pit.

We had also considered defining an empty DIO port on each robot‚Äôs rio as the port that tells the robot which code should be running, which may be the best option given our team‚Äôs robustness requirements. A dupont connector and some hotglue would do here I think.

Overall, the issues we are trying to solve are very niche and lie outside the realm of probable outcomes, but even so, if it is possible to check this at compile time that would be our preference.

posts.name: Gavin Matthews
posts.cooked:
Gandagorn:

We may not have time to implement that one line adjustment before we have to be out on the field.

Gandagorn:

the file needs to be added back to the new rio, which may be forgotten in the hustle and bustle of a busy pit.

You get to choose what happens when you can‚Äôt identify the robot.  Refusing to run is probably too hard-core for you, so you should pick one robot as default, and emit warnings (maybe a Persistent Alert).  You‚Äôll see in the thread I linked that I recommend putting the robot name at the top of the dashboard.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
bovlb:

You get to choose what happens when you can‚Äôt identify the robot. Refusing to run is probably too hard-core for you, so you should pick one robot as default, and emit warnings (maybe a Persistent Alert). You‚Äôll see in the thread I linked that I recommend putting the robot name at the top of the dashboard.

That makes sense. We know which robot is going to compete before the event starts, so setting the default is a viable solution. A persistent alert and logging the robot on the dashboard would also help in debugging when we inevitably forget to fix the serial number after a rio swap or add the file to the new rio.

Thanks everyone!

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: hm, yeah, I mean, you‚Äôre going to do a pit check anyway, you can make the code just fail the pit check if the serial number is wrong.  the error message could just be the instructions to fix it.

posts.name: Dan Katzuv
posts.cooked: You could probably add something to the deploy Gradle task that will first check the serial number of the roboRIO, and then fail if it‚Äôs not the expected one.

posts.name: Elliot Scher
posts.cooked:
We tried SSHing into our rio2 and we found that the serial number was located at:

/sys/firmware/devicetree/base/serial-number

So we‚Äôll try that in our gradle task.

The weird thing is that on a spare rio1 we had, we can‚Äôt find the serial number at the same path. Any ideas where it could be on a rio1?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
I would recommend that you at least explore using the RoboRio web interface ‚Äúcomment‚Äù box, the contents of which get stored on the Rio in /etc/machine-info or is accessible from the getComments call.

That gives you a no-code-change way to replace a Rio.
